Nunc de proprietatibus personarum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 26, xxx
. This is distinction 26 which continues the preceding, for after the Master determined about the names which are able to be said about God extrinsecally, now consequently he determines about the properties which suit God instrinsically. And this is divided into two parts because in the first place he treats the properties according to their proper being, in the second place according to their compared being. The second begins at the beginning of distinction of 27
hic quaeri potest
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 27, xxx
.

The first is divided into three because in the first place he shows how this name hypostasis should be admitted in the divine, in the second place by which names any hypostases should be named, in the third place he introduces questions and then teaches how to solve them. He begins the second here,
iam de proprietatibus
Lombardus, Sent. I, xxx
. The third begins at
hic quaeritur quomodo
Lombardus, Sent. I, xxx
.

The second principal part, namely distinction 27, is divided in three parts, for in the first place he shows how these properties relate to personal names, in the second place how they relate to non personal names, in the third place he provides a general rule with respect to substantial and notional names. The third begins at,
est hic advertenda
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 27, c. 4 (xxx).
. The second begins at,
hic non est praetermittendum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 27, c. 3 (xxx).
, etc.
Whether there are as many precise divine supposites as there relative properties amount them.

That not because in the divine there is some absolute supposite, therefore there are more supposites than properties. The consequence holds because there are precisely as many relative properties as there are relative things. The antecedent is proved because actions belong to supposites, but action formally suits the divine essence, therefore also the suppositable ratio. Again in the second place because understanding only suits supposites, but the essence understands formally, indeed essential understanding, as it seems, precedes notional understanding, therefore.

In the second place, the divine supposites are distinguished from the essence, therefore. The consequence is clear because a distinction in the divine implies a relative opposition according to Anselm, and consequently he argues for a relative property in each distinct thing, therefore in the divine essence there is a relative property distinct from the properties of the supposites. The antecedent is proved because about the essence and persons there are truly called contraries, as for example communicable and non-communicable. In the second place, the antecedent is proved because the Son is something that is not the Father, therefore the Son is something that is not the essence. The consequence is clear because whatever is the essence is the Father. The antecedent is proved because the Son is the supposite of the Son which is not the Father. In the third place, the same antecedent is proved because the essence is absolutely perfect, but no supposite is absolutely perfect, therefore.

In third place principally, it is argued there are more relative properties than supposites, therefore. The antecedent is proved because any relative property constitute a supposite. In the second place because there are as many real things internally as there are relations. In the third place, because a personal property or person and the essence are formally distinguished, as holds
Scotus, in book 1, distinction 33
Scotus, I, d. 33 , therefore.

In opposition is the
Master in these distinctions
Lombardus, Sent. I, xxx.
. Again,
Richard, IV De Trinitate, chapter 17 , says,
in the trinity there are as many personal properties as there are persons
Richardus de Sancto Victore, De Trinitate IV, 17.
, therefore.

First conclusion: just as any divine supposite
is simple and necessarily in the highest degree, so no divine supposite is properly constituted in being by a property. The first part is proved because any divine supposite is not less simple that the divine essence, but it is necessary that this being is simple in the highest degree, therefore for the supposite. The second part is proved because, if the Father were constituted in being by a property, it follows that the Father in some mode would have a cause or beginning. The consequent is false because the Father is the beginning without a beginning. And the consequence is clear because something constitutive is in some mode a cause and beginning of that which it constitutes.

First corollary: if some divine supposite were constituted in being by its own property, then every supposite would be distinguished by its own property. This is clear because everything constituting is distinguished by what it constitutes, since every thing constituting is a beginning and cause of what it constitutes, as is the proof of the conclusion states.

Second corollary: it is as repugnant that the Father is distinguished from his paternity, as it is repugnant to him that he is constituted in being by his paternity. This is clear because otherwise the same thing would constitute itself in being, which does not seem to be imaginable.

Third corollary: just it is not the case that in the divine there is some constituted supposite, so it is not the case that in the divine there is some absolute supposite. It is proved because then there would not be a trinity in the divine, but also a quaternity, just as is attributed to Father Ioachim by the
Master of the Sentences
Lombardus, Sent. I, xxx.
.
Thomas of Argentina, in book one, in distincton 26, in article 4
Thomas de Argentina, Sent. I, d. 26, a. 4.
proves this corollary.

Second conclusion: just as personal identity is repugnant to the immeasurable trinity, so the distinctive formality of a distinction is repugnant to the highest simplicity. This entire conclusion is proved in the first place through the common rule of Anselm
Anselm inDe processione Spiritus Sancti, chapter 2 , in which it is said,
all things are the same where an opposition of relation is not found
Anselmus, De processione Spiritus Sancti 7, xxx
, but only among the persons is there a relative opposition of this type, therefore in the divine only a personal distinction should be posited.

The first corollary: just in the divine there is no constitutive ratio, so between the person and the essence there is no distinctive ratio. This is clear because between the persons and essence there is no relative opposition, therefore there is no distinction. The consequence is clear through the conclusion and proof.

The second corollary: just as a person is not constituted by its property, so the divine is not composed from three persons. This is clear both because the highest simplicity and because composition imply potentiality and imperfection, just as constitution.

Third corollary: though divine essence is said about something about which Father is not said and conversely, nevertheless between the Father and the divine essence a distinction should not be posited. The first is clear because the essence is said about the Son about whom nevertheless Father is not said. The second part is clear through the conclusion.

Third conclusion: that the divine essence, person, and relative properties are formally the same thing or the same formality or identity. This is clear from the second conclusion because between these things there is no relative opposition.

First corollary: that when a personal property is abstracted through the intellect the essence does not remain in common. This is clear because these are immeasurably the same thing, as is clear from what has been said.
Saint Thomas, in the first part, in question 44
Aquinas, S.T. I, q. 44
puts the opposite of this corollary.

Second corollary: a relative property in the divine does not appear or exist in the persons, as opposed to the way of speaking of some ancient doctors. This is clear because this appearance or existence indicates some distinction.
The third corollary is the affirmative response to the what is asked.

Against the first conclusion, what constitutes a person in being is that through which this person has being and without which a person is not able to be understood. But the Son has being through being generated and without this the Son is not able to be understood, therefore the Son is constituted in being through being generated.

In the second place, that which multiplies divine persons is what constitutes them in being, but relation multiplies the Trinity, therefore relation constitutes the persons in being. The major seems known, an the minor is from
Boethius, in his book De Trinitate , where he says that,
the essence contains unity, and relation mutliples the Trinity
Boethius, De Trinitate xxx
.

In the third place against the third corollary, that which suits creatures by reason
of their perfection seems like it should be attributed to God, but in things separated from mater the supposite and nature are the same, therefore the divine essence will itself be a supposite and not something relative, therefore absolute.

in the fourth place, against the same act of speaking it presupposes the person speaking and not the relative, therefore the absolute. That it is not relative is shown because when relatives are posited at the same time, it follows that the same act of speaking would presuppose the said person, and thus it would be said before it were said, which implies a contradiction.

Against the second conclusion and first corollary, identity is greater between the Father and paternity than between the Father and essence, therefore some distinction should be put between the Father and the essence. The consequence holds because distinction and identity seem to be related through the mode of opposite latitudes.

In the second place, it is able to be argued through the second argument made in the opposite because concerning the person and essence contradictory predicates are verified. Again, because the Son is something that the Father or essence is not because it is the supposite of the Son. Again, because the divine essence is immeasurable perfection absolutely and the person is not, therefore between these there must fall a distinction.

In the third place against the third corollary, it would follows that this form is not valid, this thing is common, and this thing is not common by the same demonstrated thing, therefore the same thing is distinct from itself formally and in someway.

Against the third conclusion, it is argued with the authority of
Augustine, VII De Trinitate, in the first chapter , who says
every essence which is called a relation is also something when the relation is removed
Augustinus, De Trinitate VII, 1, 2.
. But this would not be unless there were some distinction between the essence and person and property, therefore the conclusion is false.

In the second place against the first corollary, there appears the opinion of
Augustine
VII
primo 7o
De Trinitate, chapter 2 ,
the Son is not by virtue of the Word by which he is wise because the word is not said from itself but wisdom is only truly understood relatively.
Augustinus, De Trinitate, VII, 2, 3 .

In the third place against the second corollary, there appears the saying of
Avicenna III Metaphysics, in his chapter on relation , where he says that,
paternity is a disposition having its being in the father alone
Avicenna, Metaphysics III, xxx
. Therefore it seems that paternity which is a property of the Father instantiates the Father, the opposite of which was asserted by the corollary.

Against the third corollary, if it were precisely the supposite in total, then it follows that active spiration would not be a true thing. The consequence is clear because it is not a relative property, since it is in the Father and the Son. But the falsity of the consequent is clear, since such active spiration is a real relation which does not seem able to be posited unless a real difference were posited, since every real relation or distinction requires two really distinct extremes, therefore it follows that this is a true thing.

In the fifth place, when a inferior thing is multiplied it is multiplied above, but the thing is something related to the above, therefore in total things will be in the divine which are relations, but there will be four relations there, namely active and passive generation and active and passive spiration, therefore there will be four real things.
To the first, the major is denied because no constitution is properly posited in the divine on account of composition or potentiality which such terms convey.
Similarly with respect to the second, the major is denied.

To the third, it is said that, though it is of such a perfection that the supposite does not differ from the nature, nevertheless it is not of such a perfection that for one nature there is only supposite because the essence would be more perfect if this manifestly indistinct thing had many supposites and were really the same thing, just as it is in the divine. In the second place, the minor would be able to be denied because in creatures a supposite adds something beyond the nature or somehow the being, and is a certain kind of difference between this, and they are not convertibly the same, as will be clear elsewhere.

To the fourth, it is said that the person meaning an act of speaking and person spoken with respect to reality are simultaneous, and between this there is not a praecession or presupposition, unless perhaps according to our mode of understanding which does not change anything in reality.

To the first against the second conclusion, the antecedent is denied and whatever is from the consequence because the Father is neither more nor less identified or distinguished from the essence that from paternity or the converse.

To the second, in the first place the antecedent would be able to be denied because they are not predicated with respect to the same thing. In the second place also,
the consequence would be able to be denied because according to some it is possible that one term supposites for that which is that for which another supposites, nevertheless it is does not supposite for everything for which the other supposites.

To the third, the consequence would be able to be denied, and to the proof, because whatever the Father the essence is and the converse, this is able to have two senses. First that that about whatever the essence is said the Father is said about this, and this is false because in this way the Son would be the Father. The second that every incomplex being which the essence is is this entity which the Father is, and this is true.
In the second place, the antecedent would be able to be denied because to be the Son is not something but a relation to something.

In the third place, it would be able to be said that the Son is nothing that the Father is not, and to the proof, because the Son is not the supposite of the Son which is not the Father, therefore etc, the consequence is denied because a fallacy is able to be assigned many times namely fallacy of amphiboly, of the fallacy of the consequent, and a process from the secundum quid to the simpliciter.
To the fourth, the second part of the antecedent is denied because some divine supposite is the same immense perfection which is the essence.
To the fifth, the consequent is conceded, namely that this form is not valid.

To the first against the third conclusion, it is said that Augustine wishes to say that the essence, which is said to something, is also said from itself, just he explains there, and this is not against the conclusion.

To another from this authority, it is said that he wishes to say that the Son is not the Word inasmuch as he is wisdom, thought it should be held, or inasmuch as it is reduplicative. And this is conceded as if true because otherwise the Father would be the Word, since he is wisdom and similarly the Holy Spirit also.

To the third, in the first place it is able to be said that Avicenna does not speak about God or about the divine, therefore it does not conclude. In the second place, it would be able to be absolutely denied if he wished to say that generation is really distinguished from its foundation.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied because, though it is not a distinct thing from the other three things, which are the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, nevertheless it is a true thing. See
Thomas of Strasbourg, in distinction 28 of book 1, article 2
Thomas de Argentina, Sent. I, d. 28, a. 2
.

To the fifth, the antecedent is conceded, and when it is further argued, that in one supposite, etc., it is said that in the same supposite the relations are not pluralized with respect to reality belong to something intrinsecally and directly, but only with respect to a reality of terms thought through such relations. Whence the Father is referred to the Son and the Holy Spirit by a single relation according to a thing which nevertheless corresponds to two other opposing relations, and to it belongs the relations of several species according to which many things correspond. For Socrates by the same whiteness is similar to the white Plato and dissimilar to black John etc..
The same relation according to a thing corresponds to likeness and dislikeness which are opposites. And thus likewise the same most simple thing, which is the Father, is spiration and paternity which corresponds to the filiation in the Son and spiration in the Holy Spirit. This is the position of
Gregory, in distinctions 26 and 27
Gregorius Ariminensis, Sent. I, d. 26 et 27.
.

To the first argument in the opposition, the antecedent is denied, as is clear through what has been said. And to the proof, it is said that, with the supposites circumscribed, the divine essence neither acts nor understands nor is there some action suitable to it.

In the second place, I say that the antecedent is not univerally true because in the sacrament of the alter accidents act and are acted upon, and nevertheless non accident is a supposite. From this it is clear because to this, that the ratio of activity suits something, it suffices that this has being through itself.
In the third place, I say that essential understanding does not proceed notional because some divine understanding is relative from a person because understanding in the Father is notional.

To the third, it is clear through what has been said the antecedent is false. And to the proof it is clear that the name constitution ought not to be admitted in the divine on account of composition and potentiality which imply it implies.

In the second place, I say that paternity and active spiration, though they do not constitute the person of the Father, they are nevertheless
the same most simple thing that the Father is and they are not many real things.
In the third place, I say that personal property and essence are not formally distinguished, but they are the same formally, as is clear from the third conclusion.

Nunc de proprietatibus personarum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 26, xxx
. First conclusion of distinction 26: that by the name of hypostasis
Jerome
says,
it should not be used on account of heretics because they used it poorly be then it was not in use, but now we say three hypostases, that is three persons
Hieronymus, xxx .

Second conclusion: that there are three properties or notions of three persons each of which is not the other, namely generation or paternity, nativity or filiation, and procession, which properties these names designate, namely the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

Third conclusion: that these names Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are relative and said relatively to one another because they indicate relations which are accidentals in God, but are in these persons from eternity and unchangeably.

Fourth conclusion: not all things which are said of God are said according to substance. Some are said according to substance, some are said according to relation, but nothing is said there according to accident.

Fifth conclusion: that it is proper, when God as been born, that he is the Son of God by origin not by the choice, the opposite of which was held by the heretics Nestorius et Photinus haeretici. He is also the Son in truth, not only by pronouncement, as Sabellius says, asserting that is the same person whenever we call it the Father, or the Son or the Holy Spirit. Again, he is the Son by nativity not by creation, as Arius says, stating that the Son is a creature. But men are called sons of God, indeed of the Trinity, by being made or adoption, not by the nativity of the property.

Sixth conclusion: though there are many gifts of God, nevertheless the Holy Spirit by an immutable and eternal property is thus gift, just as the Son by a property is the Son, but by this property is not called gift because the Holy Spirit, and each by a name, is called relatively, though this relation does not so appear in the name Holy Spirit, as it does in this name gift.

Seventh conclusion: that the Trinity is able to be called holy spirit because it is spirit and it is holy, and in this case Holy Spirit is not said relatively but according to the essence because properly the Holy Spirit, who is not the Trinity but in the Trinity, is said relatively.

Eight conclusion: though the Holy Spirit is said relatively to the Father and to the Son, nevertheless the Father is not said to be the Father of the Holy Spirit, though the Holy Spirit is the Spirit of the Father. Similarly, The Son is not called the Father of the Holy Spirit, though the Holy Spirit is the Spirit of the Son, nevertheless it is possible to be called the gift of the giver and the giver of the gift

Ninth: though the giver and the gift are said relative to one another, nevertheless God is not called the giver unless with respect to time, even though the gift is from eternity because the Holy Spirit is or is able to be called the giver which was from eternity.

Hic quaeri potest
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 27, c. 1, xxx
. The first conclusion of distinction 27: that according to Augustine it is proper to the Father that he generated the Son, but propert to the Son that he is generated by the Father, to the Holy Spirit that it is proceeds from both. But according to Hilary it is proper to the Father that he is always the Father, and of the Son that he always the Son, and the Holy Spirit that it is always the Holy Spirit or gift. According to others the property of the Father is paternity, of the Son filiation, and of the Holy Spirit procession, and the same properties are signified in the aforementioned words.

The second conclusion: that the name of the Father not only notes a relation, but also signifies a hypostasim, that is a substance, so also the Son and the Holy Spirit. But the names of relations, namely paternity, filiation, procession or to beget, to be begotten, to proceed signify relations not hypostases.

Third conclusion: that when it is said God is the Father, by the name Father we note the relation and signify the divine hypostasim, but when we posit the names of relations in predicates, we only signify notions, not hypostases, as is the case when we say God generated, that is, he has the Son.
Fourth conclusion: that individual properties property suit the persons at the same time, and through these the persons are determined and differ from one another and do not recede from one another.

Fifth conclusion: names are different things which signify persons and denote the properties of them, namely begetter, begotten, word, image, whence word is said relatively to that of which it is an image.

Sixth conclusion: that the Son by the same property or notion is called word and image because the Son but in that in which word is said wisdom or the essence is said because wisdom or essence are both said relatively just as the word.

Seventh conclusion: that though God according to substance is called light, wisdom, and things of this type and never relatively, nevertheless sometimes it is said for related things, that is for persons, but it is not understood relatively, as when it is said God from God, light from light, one instance stands for the Father and the other for the Son.

Eight conclusion: that the word from word is not able to be said because both words are not at the same time because Father is not the word, nor image from image nor son from son because image and son they are not at the same time, but only the son, image, or word is.

Ninth conclusion: that sometimes the names of the substances signify persons, as when it is said God generated God. Sometimes they signify the entire Trinity, as is clear when it is said no one is good except God alone. And this suffices for the present lecture.
